--- Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> I agree with Colin's approach of setting the fitness
> to some very 
> low value;  you can just ignore the outputs if they
> don't stabilize.
> But also note that to make meaningful comparisons
> with other 
> people's XOR results, you should technically disable
> the ability for 
> NEAT to add recurrent connections.  That's because
> no one tries to 
> solve XOR with a recurrent network- they always use
> feedforward 
> solutions.  It's kind of interesting that NEAT finds
> a recurrent 
> solution, but it ruins comparisons with other
> methods since they 
> don't have the ability to do that so it isn't really
> fair.  I 
> disabled the addition of recurrent connections for
> my XOR 
> experiments.

It's true that there is not much point to a recurrent
ANN that does XOR, but I did one anyway, just as a
demonstration.  You can see it operate by downloading
the VizANN package from the URL below.  (It's written
in Python.)  It has two neurons.

My approach to the problem of how to know when the
computation is finished is to use one output of the
net as a "ready" line.  You start with all outputs at
zero.  As soon as the "ready" output is high, then you
are done.  High could be defined as > .5.  I think
this is a general approach that applies to many
problems.  Essentially, you are letting the nework
tell you when it is done processing.
